subject: Languages
title: Gendered Languages Shape Perception
description: A micro-lesson that makes Gendered Languages Shape Perception usable.

hook.text: In Spanish, a bridge is feminine. In German, it's masculine. This changes how people describe it.

buildup.text: Studies by Lera Boroditsky showed that grammatical gender affects how people perceive objects.

discovery.text: Spanish speakers described bridges as 'elegant' and 'slender.' Germans called them 'strong' and 'sturdy.'

twist.text: The objects are identical â€” but the grammar makes speakers associate them with gendered traits.

climax.text: This means translation between gendered and non-gendered languages carries invisible biases.

punchline.text: Grammar doesn't just organize sentences â€” it colors how we see the world.

quiz.question: How does grammatical gender affect perception?
options: People describe objects with traits matching the word's gender
